title: Getting started
text: vignette show get started likelihoodTools package. likelihoodTools package provides set tools help work likelihood package (Murphy 2023). use dataset example included likelihood illustrate use likelihoodTools package. show create model function, compute MLE parameters (steps likelihood package), use likelihoodTools package : () extract main information MLE results, (ii) plot residuals vs. predicted values, (iii) plot residuals vs. observed values.

what: Maximum Likelihood Estimation of the models parameters
title: Getting started
text: indicated likelihood package first step formulate model function, compute MLE parameters. , compute MLE parameters using anneal function likelihood package.
code: data(crown_rad) dataset <- crown_rad modelfun <- function (a, b, DBH) {a + b * DBH} results <- anneal(model = modelfun,                   par = list(a = 0, b = 0),                   var = list(DBH = "DBH", x = "Radius", mean = "predicted",                              sd = 0.815585, log = TRUE),                   source_data = dataset,                   par_lo = list(a = 0, b = 0),                   par_hi = list(a = 50, b = 50),                   pdf = dnorm,                   dep_var = "Radius",                   max_iter = 20000,                   show_display = FALSE)

what: Extract the main information from the MLE results
title: Getting started
text: likellihood::anneal() function returns list object information annealing run. list-type object contains several information (see likellihood::anneal() details). mle_format() function likelihoodTools package allows extract main information MLE results user-friendly way. can plot table style using thekableExtra (Zhu 2024) package. MLE Results
code: mle_format(results, yvar = "Radius") #>   max_likeli n_params  aic_cor      aic        R2     slope      rmse #> 1  -119.7453        2 243.6156 243.4906 0.4450001 0.9999627 0.8151813 m <- mle_format(results, yvar = "Radius")  # Rename the columns colnames(m) <- c(   "Maximum Likelihood",    "# Params.",    "AIC~cor~",    "AIC",    "R^2^",    "Slope",    "RMSE" )  # Print the results in a table library(kableExtra) kable(m, escape = FALSE, caption = "MLE Results", digits = 3) |>    kable_styling(full_width = F, position = "center", bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"))

what: Plot the residuals vs. predicted values
title: Getting started
text: mle_plot_residuals() function allows plot residuals (observed - residuals) values vs. predicted values. predicted values obtained model parameters values estimated maximum likelihood estimation using simulated annealing.

what: Plot the predicted vs. observed values
title: Getting started
text: mle_plot_observed() function allows plot predicted values vs. observed values. predicted values obtained model parameters values estimated maximum likelihood estimation using simulated annealing.

title: Getting started
text: don’t like default plot, can customize using ggplot2 (@ Wickham 2016) parameters. example, can increase size points, change color, change axis titles, etc.
code: p_observed +   ggplot2::geom_point(size = 2, color = "red") +   ggplot2::labs(x = "Observed Radius", y = "Predicted Radius") +   ggplot2::theme(     axis.title.x = ggplot2::element_text(size = 13, face = "bold"),     axis.title.y = ggplot2::element_text(size = 13, face = "bold")   )

what: Plot the distribution of the residuals
title: Getting started
text: Maybe user interested plot distribution residuals. provided code .  Now, can add distribution histogram. , used MASS package (Venables Ripley 2002).
code: library(ggplot2) library(dplyr)  # compute the residuals d <- results$source_data |>    dplyr::mutate(residuals = Radius - predicted)  # plot the histogram p_residuals_dist <- ggplot(data = d, aes(x = residuals)) +   geom_histogram(aes(y = after_stat(density), x = residuals),                     fill = "gray", col = "white", bins = 30) +   theme_bw() +   theme(panel.grid = element_blank()) +   xlab("Residuals") +   ylab("Density")  p_residuals_dist library(MASS)  # estimate the distribution of the residuals   dist <- MASS::fitdistr(d$residuals, "normal")  params <- as.data.frame(t(dist$estimate))   p_residuals_dist <- p_residuals_dist  + stat_function(fun = dnorm,                args = list(mean = params$mean,                            sd = params$sd),                color = "black", size = 1)  #> Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead. #> This warning is displayed once every 8 hours. #> Call `lifecycle::last_lifecycle_warnings()` to see where this warning was #> generated.

title: Getting started
text: Maybe user intereseted arrange residuals plots, observed vs.  predicted error distribution plots single plot. several packages patchwork (Pedersen 2024) cowplot (Wilke 2024) allow . , provide simple code .
code: library(patchwork)   (p_observed + p_residuals + p_residuals_dist +  plot_annotation(tag_levels = "a")) &    theme(axis.title = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold"),          axis.text = element_text(size = 11),         plot.tag = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold"))

what: Tools for managing results from Maximum Likelihood Estimation
title: Tools for managing results from Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: likelihoodTools package provides tools managing exploring parameter estimation results derived Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE) using likelihood package. package simplifies analysis workflows offering functions support organization, visualization, summary MLE outcomes, aiding deeper statistical insights. package designed simplify exploration interpretation MLE results, providing comprehensive set tools managing parameter estimation outcomes.

title: Tools for managing results from Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: can install development version likelihoodTools GitHub :

title: Tools for managing results from Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: Tools organizing MLE outputs. Functions explore, visualize, interpret parameter estimation results. Integrations dplyr ggplot2 efficient data manipulation visualization.

what: Extract and format results from Simulated Annealing (Maximum Likelihood Estimation) — mle_format
title: Extract and format results from Simulated Annealing (Maximum Likelihood Estimation) — mle_format
text: Extract format results Simulated Annealing (Maximum Likelihood Estimation)

title: Extract and format results from Simulated Annealing (Maximum Likelihood Estimation) — mle_format
Extract and format results from Simulated Annealing (Maximum Likelihood Estimation) — mle_format
text: x List results simulated annealing algorithm Maximum Likelihood Estimation. See likelihood::anneal() yvar name column contains dependent variable (“observed” value). column must present source_data x (results) list

title: Extract and format results from Simulated Annealing (Maximum Likelihood Estimation) — mle_format
text: dataframe outputs results simulated annealing maximum parameter estimation. dataframe contains following columns (see help likelihood::anneal()): max_likeli maximum likelihood value model n_params number estimated parameters aic_corr value Akaike's Information Criterion “corrected” small sample size. See "Simulated Annealing Algorithm" help page likelihood package information. aic value Akaike's Information Criterion. See "Simulated Annealing Algorithm" help page likelihood package information. slope Slope observed values linearly regressed predicted model, using parameter maximum likelihood estimates. intercept forced zero. R2	Proportion variance explained model relative explained simple mean data. rmse Root Mean Square Error, .e. standard deviation residuals. computed : $$RMSE=\sqrt{ \frac{\sum_{=1}^{N}(obs_i - exp_i)^2}{n -1}}$$

title: Extract and format results from Simulated Annealing (Maximum Likelihood Estimation) — mle_format
code: # Get the results of the maximum likelihood estimation from the example in # the anneal function of the likelihood pkg.  library(likelihood) #> Loading required package: nlme data(crown_rad) dataset <- crown_rad  # Create our model function modelfun <- function (a, b, DBH) {a + b * DBH}  # Compute the MLE of the parameters results <- anneal(model = modelfun,   par = list(a = 0, b = 0),   var = list(DBH = "DBH", x = "Radius", mean = "predicted",              sd = 0.815585, log = TRUE),   source_data = dataset,   par_lo = list(a = 0, b = 0),   par_hi = list(a = 50, b = 50),   pdf = dnorm,   dep_var = "Radius",   max_iter = 20000,   show_display = FALSE)  # Format the results mle_format(results, yvar = "DBH") #>   max_likeli n_params  aic_cor      aic        R2     slope    rmse #> 1  -119.7453        2 243.6156 243.4906 0.4450001 0.9999627 18.9791

title: Plots Observed vs. Predicted MLE — mle_plot_observed
text: x List results simulated annealing algorithm Maximum Likelihood Estimation. See likelihood::anneal() yvar name column contains dependent variable (“observed” value). column must present source_data x (results) list annotate logical (default TRUE), display values \(R^2\) slope regression observed predicted values. See likelihood::Simulated Annealing Algorithm lab_x text x-axis lab lab_y text y-axis lab ... ggplot2 parameters
